title: A common bacterial metabolite elicits prion-based bypass of glucose repression
abstract: Robust preference for fermentative glucose metabolism has motivated domestication of the budding yeast <italic>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</italic>. This program can be circumvented by a protein-based genetic element, the [<italic>GAR</italic><sup>+</sup>] prion, permitting simultaneous metabolism of glucose and other carbon sources. Diverse bacteria can elicit yeast cells to acquire [<italic>GAR</italic><sup>+</sup>], although the molecular details of this interaction remain unknown. Here we identify the common bacterial metabolite lactic acid as a strong [<italic>GAR</italic><sup>+</sup>] inducer. Transient exposure to lactic acid caused yeast cells to heritably circumvent glucose repression. This trait had the defining genetic properties of [<italic>GAR</italic><sup>+</sup>], and did not require utilization of lactic acid as a carbon source. Lactic acid also induced [<italic>GAR</italic><sup>+</sup>]-like epigenetic states in fungi that diverged from <italic>S. cerevisiae</italic> ~200 million years ago, and in which glucose repression evolved independently. To our knowledge, this is the first study to uncover a bacterial metabolite with the capacity to potently induce a prion.
